case_name: State of Assam v. Bimal Kumar Pandit

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 22, 1962, of the Assam High Court in Gauhati, in Civil Rule No. 369 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 22, 1962, of the Assam High Court in Gauhati, in Civil Rule No. 369 of 1961.

facts.text: The respondent Bimal Kumar Pandit was serving appellant No. 1, the State of Assam, as an Extra-Assistant Commissioner, Shillong.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Bimal Kumar Pandit was serving appellant No. 1, the State of Assam, as an Extra-Assistant Commissioner, Shillong.

facts.text: On December 11, 1959, the second appellant, the Chief Secretary to the Government of Assam, served on the respondent a charge-sheet containing eleven specific charges.

anchor.surface_text: On December 11, 1959, the second appellant, the Chief Secretary to the Government of Assam, served on the respondent a charge-sheet containing eleven specific charges and called upon him to show cause why he should not be dismissed from service or otherwise punished under Rule 55 of the Civil Services Classification, Control Appeal Rules read with Art. 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The Governor of Assam had been pleased to authorise the Commissioner of Plains Division, Assam, to conduct the enquiry and to report to appellant No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: The said notice further informed the respondent that the Governor of Assam had been pleased to authorise the Commissioner of Plains Division, Assam, to conduct the. enquiry and to report to appellant No. 2.

facts.text: On January 13, 1960 the respondent submitted an elaborate explanation in respect of all the charges.

anchor.surface_text: On January 13, 1960 the respondent submitted an elaborate explanation in respect of all the charges.

facts.text: The Commissioner of Plains Division, Assam, held an enquiry and made the report on April 12, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Plains Division, Assam, then proceeded to hold an enquiry and after considering the evidence adduced before him, he made the report on April 12, 1960.

facts.text: Enquiry officer found that out of the 11 charges, 6 had not been proved and of the remaining 5 charges, two (charges 7 and 10) had been fully established and the other three (Nos. 1, 2 and 4) had been partially established.

anchor.surface_text: In this report the Enquiry officer found that out of the 11 charges drawn up against the respondent, 6 had number been proved and of the remaining 5 charges, two had been fully established-they were charges 7 and 10 and the other three charges Nos. 1 , 2 and 4 had been partially established.

facts.text: The report recommended that withholding of three increments from his pay would meet the ends of justice.

anchor.surface_text: the with. holding of three increments from his pay would meet the ends of justice in this case.

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 served a second notice on the respondent on June 1, 1960 under Article 311(2), requiring explanation why penalty of removal from service should not be imposed, with copy of enquiry report enclosed.

anchor.surface_text: After this report was received, appellant No. .2 served a second numberice on the respondent on June 1, 1960. This numberice referred to the disciplinary proceedings held against the respondent and added that the respondent was thereby required under clause 2 of Art. 311 of the Constitution to submit his explanation if any, why the penalty of removal from service should number be imposed upon him. The numberice further stated that a companyy of the report of the Enquiring officer in the disciplinary proceedings drawn up against the respondent was enclosed.

facts.text: The respondent was told that he had to submit his explanation on or before June 18, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was told that he had to submit his explanation through the Commissioner of Plains Division, Assam, on or before June 18, 1960.

facts.text: On June 21, 1960 the respondent submitted his explanation in respect of the charges held proved by the Enquiring officer.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving this numberice, the respondent submitted his explanation on June 21, 1960 in respect of the charges which had been held proved by-the Enquiring officer.

facts.text: On July 8, 1961, the Governor of Assam ordered reduction in rank of the respondent to Assam Civil Service Class II permanently.

anchor.surface_text: After considering the explanation thus submitted by the respondent, the Governor of Assam was pleased to reduce in rank the respondent who was on probation in the Assam Civil Service, Class I to the Assam Civil Service Class Il, perma- nently, with effect from the date he takes over as such.

facts.text: The respondent challenged the validity of this order by a writ petition in the High Court of Judicature at Assam on August 24, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then challenged the validity of this order by a writ petition in the High Court of .Judicature at Assam on August, 24, 1961.

facts.text: High Court allowed the writ petition and issued a mandamus directing the appellants not to give effect to the order dated July 8, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court has allowed the writ petition and issued a mandamus directing the appellants number to give effect to the order dated 8th July, 1961.

facts.text: Appellants came to this Court by special leave against the High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellants have companye to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: The second notice did not clearly indicate that appellant No. 1 accepted the findings of the Enquiring officer.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents companytention which has been accepted by the High Court is that in the said numberice, appellant No. 1 has number clearly indicated that it accepted the findings of the Enquiring officer

facts.text: High Court held that the notice under Art. 311(2) contravened the requirements as it did not state acceptance of findings and reasons.

anchor.surface_text: According to the High Court, in recording such companyclusions, the dismissing authority must also indicate the reasons on which it had companye to those companyclusions against the delinquent officer and since the impugned numberice did number companytain a specific averment that the dismissing authority had accepted the findings of the enquiring officer and otherwise gave numbergrounds or reasons for the action proposed to be taken against the respondent, it companytravened the requirements of Art. 311 2 and so, it must be held to be void.

facts.text: The affidavit made by appellant No. 2 shows that before the impugned notice was served, the Government had accepted the findings of the enquiring officer.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, we may add that in the present case, the affidavit made by appellant No. 2 clearly shows that before the impugned numberice was served on the respondent, the Government had accepted the findings of the enquiring officer which means that the Government agreed with the enquiring officer in regard to both sets of findings recorded by him.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the notice afforded reasonable opportunity under Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do number think that the failure to state expressly that the dismissing authority has accepted the findings recorded in the report against the delinquent officer, justifies the companyclusion that the numberice given in that behalf does number afford a reasonable opportunity to the delinquent officer under Art. 311 2 .

facts.text: The appeal succeeds, High Court order set aside, writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the High Court was in error in companying to the companyclusion that the order of demotion Passed against the respondent in the present case was invalid on the ground that the respondent had number been given a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the said action under Art. 311 2 . The appeal accordingly succeeds, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 22, 1962, of the Assam High Court in Gauhati, in Civil Rule No. 369 of 1961.
The respondent then challenged the validity of this order by a writ petition in the High Court of .Judicature at Assam on August, 24, 1961.

On December 11, 1959, the second appellant, the Chief Secretary to the Government of Assam, served on the respondent a charge-sheet containing eleven specific charges and called upon him to show cause why he should not be dismissed from service or otherwise punished under Rule 55 of the Civil Services Classification, Control Appeal Rules read with Art. 311 of the Constitution.

concepts.interpretation: The second notice under Article 311(2) need not expressly state acceptance of the enquiry officer's findings if a copy of the report is provided, as acceptance is implied; express statement required only if authority differs from findings.

issues.text: short question about the scope and effect of the provisions contained in Article 311(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises a short question about the scope and effect of the provisions contained in Article 311  2  of the Constitution.

issues.text: if the dismissing authority does not expressly say that it has accepted the findings of the enquiring officer against the delinquent officer, does that introduce such an infirmity in the proceedings as to make the final order invalid

anchor.surface_text: But the question which calls for our decision is if the dismissing authority does not expressly say that it has accepted the findings of the enquiring officer against the delinquent officer, does that introduce such an infirmity in the proceedings as to make the final order invalid ?

issues.text: whether he had been given a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action which was ultimately taken against him under Art. 311(2)

anchor.surface_text: One of the points urged by him was that he had not been given a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action which was ultimately taken against him under Art. 311  2  and he urged that the contravention of Art. 311  2  rendered the impugned order invalid.

issues.text: if the dismissing authority differs from the findings recorded in the enquiry report, it is necessary that its provisional conclusions in that behalf should be specified in the second notice

anchor.surface_text: We ought, however, to add that if the dismissing authority differs from the findings recorded in the enquiry report, it is necessary that its provisional conclusions in that behalf should be specified in the second notice.

issues.text: the notice issued under Art. 311(2) must show that the dismissing authority has applied its mind to the findings of the Enquiring officer and has accepted the said findings against the delinquent officer

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that the notice issued under Art. 311  2  must show that the dismissing authority has applied its mind to the findings of the Enquiring officer and has accepted the said findings against the delinquent officer.

issues.text: in coming to this conclusion, the High Court has misinterpreted the scope and effect of Art. 311(2)

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad for the appellants contends that in coming to this conclusion, the High Court has misinterpreted the scope and effect of Art. 311  2 .

arguments.claim: The second notice under Art. 311(2) did not clearly indicate that the dismissing authority accepted the findings of the Enquiring officer, so the respondent could not know the grounds for the proposed penalty of removal.

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to the second notice served on the respondent under Art. 311(2). The respondents contention which has been accepted by the High Court is that in the said notice, appellant No. 1 has not clearly indicated that it accepted the findings of the Enquiring officer and since such a statement is not made in the notice, the respondent could not have known on what ground appellant No.1 provisionally decided to impose upon the respondent the penalty of removal from service.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Court seems to have taken the view that in order that the public officer may have a reasonable opportunity, tile dismissing authority must indicate i

arguments.court_reasoning: Issuance of notice with copy of report implies acceptance; express statement not mandatory unless differing from findings.

arguments.claim: The notice under Art. 311(2) must show that the dismissing authority has applied its mind to the findings, accepted them, stated conclusions, and indicated reasons for those conclusions against the delinquent officer.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that the notice issued under Art. 311(2) must show that the dismissing authority has applied its mind to the findings of the Enquiring officer and has accepted the said findings against the delinquent officer. In other words the notice should expressly state the conclusions of the dismissing authority, because unless these conclusions are communicated to the delinquent officer, he would not be able to make an adequate or effective representation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e findings recorded in the enquiry report, it is necessary that its provisional companyclusions in that behalf should be specified in the second numbe

arguments.court_reasoning: Misinterprets Art. 311(2); acceptance implied when report enclosed and notice issued proposing action.

arguments.claim: The High Court has misinterpreted the scope and effect of Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad for the appellants contends that in coming to this conclusion, the High Court has misinterpreted the scope and effect of Art. 311(2).

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the enquiry report and then indicate the nature of the action proposed to be taken against the delinquent officer. Without such an express statement i

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; no constitutional requirement for express acceptance if implied.

arguments.claim: A public officer is entitled to two opportunities: first at enquiry with natural justice, second to show cause against proposed action after dismissing authority considers report.

anchor.surface_text: It is not well settled that a public officer against whom disciplinary proceedings are intended to be taken is entitled to have two opportunities before disciplinary action is finally taken against him. An enquiry must be held and it must be conducted according to the rules prescribed in that behalf and consistently with the requirements of natural justice.

arguments.claim: Desirable but not mandatory for second notice to expressly state acceptance of enquiry findings; implied by enclosing report and proposing action.

anchor.surface_text: It may be conceded that it is desirable that the dismissing authority should indicate in the second notice its concurrence with the conclusions of the enquiring officer before it issues the said notice under Art. 311(2). But the question which calls for our decision is if the dismissing authority does not expressly say that it has accepted the findings of the enquiring officer against the delinquent officer, does that introduce such an infirmity in the proceedings as to make the final order invalid?

arguments.claim: If dismissing authority differs from enquiry findings, must specify provisional conclusions in second notice.

anchor.surface_text: We ought, however, to add that if the dismissing authority differs from the findings recorded in the enquiry report, it is necessary that its provisional conclusions in that behalf should be specified in the second notice.

arguments.claim: In this case, affidavit shows Government accepted findings before notice; thus reasonable opportunity afforded.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, we may add that in the present case, the affidavit made by appellant No. 2 clearly shows that before the impugned notice was served on the respondent, the Government had accepted the findings of the enquiring officer which means that the Government agreed with the enquiring officer in regard to both sets of findings recorded by him.

arguments.claim: Severity of proposed punishment does not imply disagreement with enquiry findings not held proved; enquiry officer not required to recommend punishment.

anchor.surface_text: His argument is that the enquiry report had suggested that the withholding of three increments would meet the ends of justice in the present case, nevertheless the notice issued by the appellants indicated that the action proposed to be taken was the respondents removal from service.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rt of this companyclusion, the learned Chief justice has observed that the public servant must have an opportunity to show cause number only against t

arguments.court_reasoning: Enquiry officer's recommendation outside scope; punishment justified on proved charges.

arguments.claim: Section 240(3) GI Act 1935 requires communication of enquiry results/findings, not authority's reasons for accepting them.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of The High Commissioner of India v. I. M. Lal, the Federal Court had to consider the scope and effect of the provisions of s. 240(3) of the Constitution Act of 1935. ... the grounds to the judgment refers are the findings or conclusions reached by the enquiring officer.

arguments.claim: Khem Chand does not require stating acceptance in notice.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in the case of Khem Chand v. The Union of India, this Court has held that Reasonable opportunity envisaged by Art. 311(2) includes... But this does not mean that in every case, the appropriate authority is under a constitutional obligation to state in the notice that it has accepted the adverse findings.

arguments.claim: State of Orissa v. Govindadas supports: similar notice upheld without express acceptance.
Andhra v. Ramayya: where authority differs on charge, must communicate conclusion, but not reasons.
arguments.court_reasoning: Justified on facts where differed, but not general rule requiring reasons.

arguments.claim: Bimal Charan Mitra and Krishan Gopal erroneous: no need for punishing authority's findings separately.
State of Bombay v. Gajanan: requires communicating enquiry findings as grounds, not authority's acceptance/reasons.

holdings.text: The failure of the dismissing authority to expressly state in the second notice under Article 311(2) that it accepts the findings of the enquiring officer does not introduce an infirmity making the final order invalid, as acceptance is implied by enclosing the enquiry report and proposing action thereon.

anchor.surface_text: But the question which calls for our decision is if the dismissing authority does not expressly say that it has accepted the findings of the enquiring officer against the delinquent officer, does that introduce such an infirmity in the proceedings as to make the final order invalid ? We are not prepared to answer this question in the affirmative. It seems to us that it would be plain to the delinquent officer that the issuance of the notice indicating the provisional conclusions of the dismissing authority as to the punishment that should be imposed on him, obviously and clearly implies that the findings recorded against him by the enquiring officer have been accepted by the dismissing authority otherwise there would be no sense and no purpose in issuing the notice under Art. 311(2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issuance of notice with enquiry report copy and proposed punishment implies acceptance of findings; desirable but not constitutionally required; supported by precedents like I.M. Lal and Govindadas.

holdings.text: If the dismissing authority differs from the findings in the enquiry report, it is necessary to specify its provisional conclusions in the second notice under Article 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: We ought, however, to add that if the dismissing authority differs from the findings recorded in the enquiry report, it is necessary that its provisional conclusions in that behalf should be specified in the second notice. It may be that the report makes findings in favour of the delinquent officer, but the dismissing authority disagrees with the said findings and proceeds to issue the notice under Art. 311(2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: To ensure reasonable opportunity, delinquent must know basis of proposed action when authority rejects favourable findings; necessary for effective representation.

holdings.text: Where the dismissing authority accepts the enquiry report in its entirety, it is not essential to expressly state such acceptance in the notice under Article 311(2), though desirable.

anchor.surface_text: But where the dismissing authority purports to proceed to issue the notice against the delinquent officer after accepting the enquiry report in its entirety it cannot be said that it is essential that the dismissing authority must say that it has so accepted the report. As we have already indicated, it is desirable that even in such cases a statement to that effect should be made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words of Article 311(2) do not mandate express statement when report enclosed makes acceptance obvious; common sense reading suffices.

holdings.text: In the present case, the second notice afforded the respondent a reasonable opportunity under Article 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do not think that the failure to state expressly that the dismissing authority has accepted the findings recorded in the report against the delinquent officer, justifies the conclusion that the notice given in that behalf does not afford a reasonable opportunity to the delinquent officer under Art. 311(2). On receiving the notice in the present case, it must have been obvious to the respondent that, the findings recorded against him by the enquiring officer had been accepted by the appellants

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit confirms pre-notice acceptance; report enclosed; respondent responded to proved charges.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in holding the demotion order invalid for lack of reasonable opportunity under Article 311(2); appeal succeeds and writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the order of demotion Passed against the respondent in the present case was invalid on the ground that the respondent had not been given a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the said action under Art. 311(2). The appeal accordingly succeeds, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misinterpretation of Article 311(2) scope by High Court; notice compliant as per above holdings.

holdings.text: The enquiry officer is not required to specify or recommend punishment in the absence of rules to the contrary.

anchor.surface_text: As this Court has held in A. N. D'Silva v. Union of India, in the absence of rules or any statutory provisions to the contrary, the enquiry officer is not required to specify the punishment which may be imposed on the delinquent officer. His task is merely to hold an enquiry into the charges and make his report setting forth his conclusions and findings in respect of the said charges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from A.N. D'Silva; enquiry limited to charges, punishment for authority; rejects inference of disagreement from punishment severity.

holdings.text: High Court decisions in Bimal Charan Mitra v. State of Orissa and Krishan Gopal Mukherjee v. The State erroneously require communication of punishing authority's separate findings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Not required by Article 311(2); contradicts settled law on implied acceptance via report.

anchor.surface_text: The last decision to which reference must be made is the decision of the Bombay High Court in the State of Bombay v. Gajanan Mahadev Badley  2  . In this case, Chief justice Chagla has observed that under Art. 311  2  it is number sufficient that the State should call upon the servant to show cause against the quantum of punishment intended to be inflicted upon him the State must also call upon the servant to show cause against the decision arrived at by a departmental enquiry if that decision companystitutes the ground on which the Government proposes to take, action against the servant.

edges.explanation: Holding h1 states that failure to expressly state acceptance does not introduce infirmity, directly addressing issue i2.

anchor.surface_text: But the question which calls for our decision is if the dismissing authority does not expressly say that it has accepted the findings of the enquiring officer against the delinquent officer, does that introduce such an infirmity in the proceedings as to make the final order invalid ? We are not prepared to answer this question in the affirmative. It seems to us that it would be plain to the delinquent officer that the issuance of the notice indicating the provisional conclusions of the dismissing authority as to the punishment that should be imposed on him, obviously and clearly implies that the findings recorded against him by the enquiring officer have been accepted by the dismissing authority otherwise there would be no sense and no purpose in issuing the notice under Art. 311(2).
The appeal accordingly succeeds, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: tate o Andhra v. T. Ramayya Suri the Andhra Pradesh High Court has held that under Art. 311  2  the authority companycerned should necessarily in its

edges.explanation: Holding h2 specifies necessity to communicate provisional conclusions when differing from enquiry report, directly addressing i4.

anchor.surface_text: We ought, however, to add that if the dismissing authority differs from the findings recorded in the enquiry report, it is necessary that its provisional conclusions in that behalf should be specified in the second notice. It may be that the report makes findings in favour of the delinquent officer, but the dismissing authority disagrees with the said findings and proceeds to issue the notice under Art. 311(2).
The appeal accordingly succeeds, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

But where the dismissing authority purports to proceed to issue the notice against the delinquent officer after accepting the enquiry report in its entirety it cannot be said that it is essential that the dismissing authority must say that it has so accepted the report. As we have already indicated, it is desirable that even in such cases a statement to that effect should be made.
The appeal accordingly succeeds, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 concludes that reasonable opportunity was afforded in the case, addressing whether reasonable opportunity was given under i3.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do not think that the failure to state expressly that the dismissing authority has accepted the findings recorded in the report against the delinquent officer, justifies the conclusion that the notice given in that behalf does not afford a reasonable opportunity to the delinquent officer under Art. 311(2). On receiving the notice in the present case, it must have been obvious to the respondent that, the findings recorded against him by the enquiring officer had been accepted by the appellants
The appeal accordingly succeeds, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.

In the result, we hold that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the order of demotion Passed against the respondent in the present case was invalid on the ground that the respondent had not been given a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the said action under Art. 311(2). The appeal accordingly succeeds, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.
